results.snippet: WE all laughed when Disney decided to make a film based on a theme-park ride. Then Johnny Depp appeared on screen in Gore Verbinski's PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: THE CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL (2003), and all bets were off. There's a kidnapping and a...
results.lead_paragraph: WE all laughed when Disney decided to make a film based on a theme-park ride. Then Johnny Depp appeared on screen in Gore Verbinski's PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: THE CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL (2003), and all bets were off. There's a kidnapping and a cursed pirate crew who turn into skeletons in the moonlight, but the show belongs to Mr. Depp's character, Capt. Jack Sparrow, a pirate with rock-star style and a well-developed sense of self. Early on, he saves the governor's daughter (Keira Knightley), who has fallen off a cliff during an unwelcome marriage proposal. The ungrateful proposer, Commodore Norrington (Jack Davenport), tells Sparrow, ''You are without a doubt the worst pirate I've ever heard of.'' Sparrow replies, ''But you have heard of me'' -- Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz. You have to say one thing for Max Schreck in NOSFERATU (1922), F. W. Murnau's vampire classic. He knows how to play undead. As creepy as Willem Dafoe was, playing Schreck in ''Shadow of the Vampire,'' about the making of this German silent, he's a grade-school trick-or-treater compared with the real thing. Count Orlok (Schreck) wants to buy a house in the town of Wisborg, and Hutter (Gustav von Wangenheim) is the unlucky real estate agent assigned to go to Transylvania to arrange the sale. ''Travel quickly, travel well, young friend, to the country of ghosts,'' says his boss. Orlok is so brazen that he marches right into town carrying his coffin. Before you can say black plague, the citizens of Wisborg are dropping like flies -- Sunday at midnight on TCM.

results.abstract: Behind the Wheel column reviews 2004 Oldsmobile Alero; photo (M)

headline.main: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2004 Oldsmobile Alero; Not With a Bang but a Whimper

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: OLDSMOBILE DIVISION OF GENERAL MOTORS CORP

results.snippet: OLDSMOBILE, the oldest American automaker to reach the modern era, died on April 29, 2004, after a long illness complicated by faulty prescriptions and parental neglect. It was 107.    The eldest child of the General Motors Corporation -- indeed, it...
results.lead_paragraph: OLDSMOBILE, the oldest American automaker to reach the modern era, died on April 29, 2004, after a long illness complicated by faulty prescriptions and parental neglect. It was 107. The eldest child of the General Motors Corporation -- indeed, it was born 11 years before its adoptive parent -- Olds built its reputation with comfortable, stylish, technologically advanced cars for the aspiring middle class.

results.abstract: Rumson Country Club (NJ) golf pro Don Brigham is trying to qualify for US Open for 31st time at age 53; photo (M)

headline.main: Trying, Trying Again for a Spot in the U.S. Open

results.snippet: Don Brigham first attempted to qualify for the United States Open in 1974.    Thirty years later, Brigham still has not played in the Open, but he is still trying. He has failed 30 times to qualify for this national championship tournament, but...
results.lead_paragraph: Don Brigham first attempted to qualify for the United States Open in 1974. Thirty years later, Brigham still has not played in the Open, but he is still trying. He has failed 30 times to qualify for this national championship tournament, but imagine the satisfaction Brigham will feel today if he finally makes it, at age 53.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students share what they know about gravity and flight, and then develop marketing strategies promoting careers in aerospace to young people. Using what they have learned, they then write recommendation letters to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA).

results.abstract: National Aeronautics and Space Administration plane KC-135 simulates weightlessness through course pattern consisting of 30 to 60 parabolas ranging 8,000 to 10,000 feet in altitude over 10 miles; Gregory W Hayes, Johnson Space Center external relations director, holds that weightless flight program, which is open to college research teams, offers many benefits, including opportunity to encourage young people to get into space and technology-related careers; Aerospace Industries Association study finds that top science and technology students are more likely to be interested in emerging sciences rather than space technology; this concerns NASA, as many employees are nearing retirement just as ambititious plans for Moon and Mars exploration are being implemented; circumstances will likely leave NASA short-handed; Purdue University and University of San Diego research teams describe their experiences on KC-135; graph; photo (M)

headline.main: Free From Gravity, These Students Taste Outer Space

results.snippet: ON THE CEILING OF THE NASA KC-135 LOW-GRAVITY PLANE, over the Gulf of Mexico -- ''Feet down!''    Normally, those words are a description of the world as we know it. Feet down. Head up. Horizon level.

results.abstract: Record low voter turnout is expected as elections are held in 25 nations for 732 members of European Parliament; even most of union's 10 new members are decidely listless about their first chance to vote; Parliament's power is growing, but most of its role is lost on voters because news media does not cover EU with breadth or detail given national issues (M)

headline.main: 'Enthusiasm' Is Not a Candidate in Elections for European Union

results.snippet: On paper, this week's European elections are a formidable display of democracy: 340 million voters in 25 countries are free to elect 732 members to the European Parliament in Brussels.    But on the campaign trail, from Britain to Lithuania, reality...
results.lead_paragraph: On paper, this week's European elections are a formidable display of democracy: 340 million voters in 25 countries are free to elect 732 members to the European Parliament in Brussels. But on the campaign trail, from Britain to Lithuania, reality abruptly intrudes, and the elections quickly lose their luster for candidate and voter alike. A record low percentage of voters, 45 percent, are expected to turn up at the polls, despite the Parliament's growing power. The percentage was nearly 50 percent in 1999 and 56 percent in 1994.

results.abstract: Sen John Kerry's restlessness on campaign trail and desire to break out for walk, meal or movie is one of many facets of his style and personality that are all by invisible to most voters in era of stage-managed politics; observations on campaign trail over several months, combined with interviews with politicians and aides who spend time by his side, help flesh out one-dimensional portraits of him offered by two sides' television ads; he relentlessly polishes even well-worn stump speech segments; is diligent greeter and chronically and unapologetically late; is avid and able athlete, although he sometimes seems physicall awkward; photos (M)

headline.main: Behind the Scenes, a Restless and Relentless Kerry

results.snippet: Like a caged hamster, Senator John Kerry is restless on the road. He pokes at the perimeter of the campaign bubble that envelops him, constantly trying to break out for a walk around the block, a restaurant dinner, the latest movie.    Landing one...
results.lead_paragraph: Like a caged hamster, Senator John Kerry is restless on the road. He pokes at the perimeter of the campaign bubble that envelops him, constantly trying to break out for a walk around the block, a restaurant dinner, the latest movie. Landing one sunny day in St. Louis, Mr. Kerry wandered off the airstrip to stroll through a grass patch, leaving his security detail trying to keep him in sight while scores of staff members, supporters, police officers and journalists waited without explanation for an hour. Another afternoon on another tarmac, he tossed a baseball, then a football, then hopped on a policeman's motorcycle for a spin, all in the space of 30 minutes. Late one evening in Harrisburg, Pa., Mr. Kerry jumped from the motorcade to greet some children on a street corner.

results.abstract: Veteran civilian test pilot becomes first human to reach space in privately developed program, guiding tiny rocket ship more than 60 miles above California in flight with several white-knuckle moments; craft, SpaceShipOne, is lifted into atmosphere attached to belly of sleek plane called White Knight; both craft were designed by Burt Rutan and his company Scaled Composites with help of Microsoft billionaire Paul G Allen, who says he put $20 million into project; pilot Michael W Melvill describes scary moment when SpaceShip One rolled 90 degrees to left during rocket-fired ascent; says his trim controls had malfunctioning motor, so he switched to backup controls and was able to stabilize errant trim system, which is supposed to help control lift and drag; trim problem left plane 20 miles off course and changed angle of flight so that it reached 328,491 feet, short of hoped-for height of 360,000 feet; photos; map; chart (L)

headline.main: Manned Private Craft Reaches Space in a Milestone for Flight

results.snippet: A veteran civilian test pilot on Monday became the first human to reach space in a privately developed program, guiding a tiny rocket ship more than 60 miles above California in a flight with several white-knuckle moments.    In front of thousands of...
results.lead_paragraph: A veteran civilian test pilot on Monday became the first human to reach space in a privately developed program, guiding a tiny rocket ship more than 60 miles above California in a flight with several white-knuckle moments. In front of thousands of spectators and a teeming press corps, the squid-shaped craft, SpaceShipOne, was lifted into the atmosphere shortly after 6:30 a.m., attached to the belly of a sleek plane called the White Knight.

results.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews book Shadow Divers: The True Adventure of Two Americans Who Risked Everything to Solve One of the Last Mysteries of World War II by Robert Kurson; photos (M)

headline.main: Bones Amid the China in a Sub At the Bottom of the Atlantic

results.snippet: SHADOW DIVERS  The True Adventure of Two Americans Who Risked Everything to Solve One of the Last Mysteries of World War II  By Robert Kurson  Illustrated. 375 pages. Random House. $26.95.      The story told in Robert Kurson's new book features...
results.lead_paragraph: SHADOW DIVERS The True Adventure of Two Americans Who Risked Everything to Solve One of the Last Mysteries of World War II By Robert Kurson Illustrated. 375 pages. Random House. $26.95. The story told in Robert Kurson's new book features undersea thrills, a gripping mystery, incredible discoveries, true-blue friendship, life-or-death crises and history unfolding before the reader's eyes. In terms of finding the right material, writers of adventure nonfiction just don't get any luckier than this.

results.abstract: International Space Station crew aborts critical spacewalk when pressure in oxygen supply of one of the two astronauts begins to drop too quickly; failure occurs just 14 minutes into what was to have been six-hour foray to repair electrical circuit board providing power to one of station's gyroscopes; photo (M)

headline.main: Space Station Crew Aborts a Spacewalk

results.snippet: The International Space Station crew was forced to abort a critical spacewalk on Thursday when pressure in the oxygen supply of one of the two astronauts began to drop too quickly.    The faulty spacesuit was that of the NASA astronaut, Lt. Col....
results.lead_paragraph: The International Space Station crew was forced to abort a critical spacewalk on Thursday when pressure in the oxygen supply of one of the two astronauts began to drop too quickly. The faulty spacesuit was that of the NASA astronaut, Lt. Col. Edward Michael Fincke of the Air Force. He and the space station commander, Col. Gennadi I. Padalka of the Russian Air Force, hurriedly re-entered the station. All happened just 14 minutes after they had opened the exit hatch for a planned six-hour foray.

results.abstract: A O Scott reviews movie Spider-Man 2, directed by Sam Raimi and starring Tobey Maguire; photo (M)

headline.main: Putting Action After Feelings Of a Superhero

results.snippet: On the way out of the advance screening of ''Spider-Man 2,'' which opens tomorrow nationwide, I asked my son, who is nearly 8 and whom I had brought along for some unscientific audience research, what he thought of the movie.    As he usually does,...
results.lead_paragraph: On the way out of the advance screening of ''Spider-Man 2,'' which opens tomorrow nationwide, I asked my son, who is nearly 8 and whom I had brought along for some unscientific audience research, what he thought of the movie. As he usually does, he mentioned the scary parts and the cool parts, of which there are many. ''But there was one part,'' he said, ''that I really didn't like.'' That was when Peter Parker threw his costume in the trash and declared that he was ''Spider-Man no more.''
